title-group.subtitle: First Reported Case With Molecular Confirmation

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Surgical Pathology, Hospital Universitario de Móstoles, Madrid, Spain
2Department of Radiology, Hospital Infantil Universitario Niño Jesús, Madrid, Spain

author-notes.corresp: Daniel Azorín, Hospital Infantil Universitario Niño Jesús, Avda. Menendez Pelayo, 65, Madrid 28009, Spain Email: dazorin.hnjs@salud.madrid.org

abstract.p: Ewing sarcoma is the second most common pediatric malignant bone neoplasm after osteosarcoma. Ewing sarcoma comprises “small, round, blue-cell” tumors thought to arise from neural crest cells. The authors report the case of a 14-year-old boy that presented with a nonpainful circumscribed lesion. The radiographs showed a lytic lesion at the tibial epiphysis with a large soft tissue mass, best depicted in the magnetic resonance imaging scan that suggested an aggressive lesion. A needle biopsy of the lesion was performed. The diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma was made based on microscopic, immunohistochemical, polymerase chain reaction, and fluorescence in situ hybridization. This is the third case report about a primary epiphyseal Ewing sarcoma and the fist one with molecular confirmation.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
The World Health Organization defined Ewing sarcoma and primitive neuroectodermal tumor (PNET) as
round cell sarcomas that show varying degrees of neuroectodermal differentiation. The term Ewing sarcoma has been used for those tumors that lack evidence of neuroectodermal differentiation as assessed by light microscopy, immunohistochemistry and electron microscopy, whereas the term PNET has been employed for tumors that demonstrate neuroectodermal features as evaluated by one or more of these modalities.1(p298)

Ewing sarcoma is the second most common pediatric malignant bone neoplasm after osteosarcoma.2,3 They comprise “small, round, blue-cell” tumors thought to arise from neural crest cells. Together with the malignant peripheral neuroectodermal tumors, they now make up Ewing’s sarcoma family of tumors (ESFT).2,3 The skeletal distribution of Ewing sarcoma is evenly distributed between the axial and appendicular skeleton, and in the long bones, the diaphysis is the more typical location.2,3 Solitary involvement of the epiphysis in these tumors is rare and may lead to diagnostic and therapeutic error.4,5 Epiphyseal tumors have a very low incidence.6 The condroblastoma is the most frequent bone tumor located in the epiphyses in children.6 To the best of our knowledge, only 2 cases of primary epiphyseal localization of PNET/Ewing sarcoma in a child have been previously reported.4,5

sec.title: Case Report
sec.p: A 14-year-old boy presented since May 2010 with a 3-month history of a nonpainful, circumscribed lesion in his right ankle that had continued to grow in size gradually. Since August 2010, he referred with pain and was originally treated with nonsteroidal medication for several weeks. Plain radiographs were performed as the symptoms did not improve (Figure 1). They showed a small ill-defined moth-eaten lytic lesion at the tibial epiphysis. There was a solid periosteal reaction in the tibial metaphysis and diaphysis and a big soft tissue mass. The magnetic resonance imaging scan (Figure 2) showed infiltration of bone only at the tibial epiphysis and a bulky soft tissue mass in the posterior aspect of the ankle. The mass had very well-defined margins and a very homogeneous signal, intermediate in T1WI and not very high in T2WI, and grew surrounding the tendons and fascia, encasing but not infiltrating the structures. The presence of such a big soft tissue mass with osseous involvement lead to think of an aggressive lesion, and a needle biopsy was performed. Macroscopically, it was a soft-tissue core of 1 cm in length. Microscopic examination of the biopsy specimen showed a diffuse growth of small, poorly differentiated cells with round nuclei containing fine chromatin and scant cytoplasm (Figure 3). Further testing including immunohistochemical staining showed that the tumor cells were diffusely positive for CD99 (Figure 4) and negative for CD45. Finally, a diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma was made based on microscopic and immunohistochemical findings. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) was negative for the commonest ESFT translocations, t(11;22) and t(21;22), but fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) showed rearrangement of EWS gene (Figure 5). Extension study showed multiple lung nodules in the chest computed tomography scan. Bone scan and bone marrow biopsy were done and did not show neoplastic infiltration. The child was treated with the SEOP 2001 chemotherapy protocol but died from the disease 1 year later.

caption.p: Plain radiograph of the right ankle: anteroposterior (A) and lateral (B) views showing a lytic, moth-eaten lesion in the tibial distal malleolus (arrowhead) with diaphyseal solid reaction (arrow). A bulky soft tissue mass is seen posteriorly (asterisk)

Magnetic resonance imaging scan of the right ankle. Sagital T1WI (A) shows epiphyseal involvement (asterisk) of the tumor and a big soft tissue mass. The signal intensity of the mass is intermediate in T1 (A and B) and not very high in T2 (C) and grows encasing but not infiltrating the tendons (arrows) and fascia
Diffuse growth of small, poorly differentiated cells with round nuclei containing fine chromatin and scant cytoplasm (hemotoxylin–eosin, 40×)
The tumor cells showed diffusely positive membranous staining for CD99 (CD99, 40×)

Tumor hybridized with the Vysis EWSR1 break-apart FISH probe (Abbott Molecular, Des Plaines, IL). The tumor cells show the 1 fusion, 1 orange, and 1 green signal pattern indicative of rearrangement of EWSR1

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Ewing sarcoma has an incidence of 1 to 2 cases/million per year.2 It is a tumor of adolescent age group, and males are affected slightly more often than females.1,5,7 Patients commonly present with pain or symptoms of osteomyelitis. Pathologic fracture can be found in about 10% to 15% of the cases.2 It usually arises in diaphyseal or metaphyseal regions in the form of an intramedullary lytic or lytic and sclerotic lesion with an aggressive lamellated periosteal reaction.8 Epiphyseal involvement may occur by extension from a primary metaphyseal or diaphyseal lesion.4,5,9

To the best of our knowledge, there are only 2 previous cases of epiphyseal Ewing sarcoma reported in the literature. The first was reported in 2003 by Muscolo et al, who published a case of a 13-year-old boy complaining of right knee pain, without a traumatic history. Radiographs showed a sclerotic lesion at the tibial epiphysis with no evidence of tumor extension to the soft tissues or the adjacent joint. Evaluation of metastatic disease was negative. The patient entered a chemotherapy protocol and after completing it a surgical resection of the upper end of the tibia was done. The histological diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma was made; however, the authors did not describe either the immunophenotype of the tumor or the molecular confirmation of such a diagnosis. The patient developed pulmonary metastases 10 months later and died.4 The second epiphyseal Ewing sarcoma was reported by Kowalczyk et al in 2011.5 They published the case of a 5-year-old girl with a history of 4 weeks of slight, intermittent limp favoring her right lower extremity without pain. Radiographs showed a large, lytic lesion in the left distal femoral epiphysis without periosteal reaction or cortex interruption, leading to an initial diagnosis of benign chondroblastoma. The patient underwent an open biopsy that revealed a diffuse growth of small, poorly differentiated cells, diffusely positive for CD99. However, cytogenetic examinations for the EWS-FLI-1 fusion gene were not performed. The child was treated with surgery and chemotherapy, remaining disease free after 2 years of follow-up.2 Our patient also showed a lytic lesion; however, unlike both previously reported cases, our patient had a big soft tissue mass, which raised the suspicion of a malignant tumor. The epiphyseal involvement, a lytic moth-eaten lesion, is that of an aggressive pattern, and the presence of a big soft tissue mass supported the idea of an aggressive tumor. The growth pattern of the soft tissue mass, encasing but not infiltrating structures, the homogeneous and not very high T2 signal, and the scarce infiltration of the bone lead to consider the diagnosis of a lymphoma.10 A synovial sarcoma was also considered, as it is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in the ankle and osseous extension is not uncommon.11 An aggressive appearing lesion in the bone associated with a big soft tissue mass always raises the suspicion of Ewing sarcoma, but the epiphyseal involvement in this case was misleading, as Ewing sarcoma is usually a diaphyseal tumor. Histologically, it showed the typical features of Ewing sarcoma, consisting of a uniform small round cell neoplasm, CD99 positive. In addition, unlike the previously reported cases, we have demonstrated the diagnostic EWS rearrangement by FISH. So, to the best of our knowledge, this is the first reported case of Ewing sarcoma in an epiphyseal location with molecular confirmation.

Epiphyseal primary location for Ewing sarcoma is very rare. Hovy6 did not find any primary malignancy in a series of 2758 epiphyseal bone tumors, with chondroblastoma being the most frequent tumor.2,4,8 However, in view of a small round cell tumor with radiological aggressive features, the histological differential diagnosis must include the group of the small round cell tumors such as neuroblastoma, small-cell osteosarcoma, mesenchymal chondrosarcoma, embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma, or lymphoblastic lymphoma.1,5,12 Immunohistochemistry will help make the diagnosis. Ewing sarcoma is positive for CD99, whereas neuroblastoma is negative.2 Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma and lymphoblastic lymphoma may stain for CD99; however, myogenin and MyoD1 in the former and CD45 and Tdt in the latter will help us make a correct diagnosis. Immunostaining for CD99 does not allow distinction of small-cell osteosarcoma and mesenchymal chondrosarcoma, making necessary the molecular evidence for EWS rearrangement.13,14 PCR is the gold standard to find any of the diagnostic translocations of Ewing sarcoma, but FISH analysis a using dual-color, break-apart EWS probe may be extremely useful,15 mainly when there has been inadequate material for PCR, as in our case.

To conclude, we think that although Ewing sarcoma is a very rare pathology in an epiphyseal location, we have to think about it any time a child has a lesion in a large bone, because a delayed diagnosis may result in severe consequences.
